instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.CHGR_ACOK: What is CHGR_ACOK? This is identical to SMC_BC_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.PM_EN_P3V3_G3H: What is PM_EN_P3V3_G3H? PM_EN_P3V3_G3H is a signal that enables the PP3V3_G3H rail to turn on. This comes out of ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip; when missing, often is missing because of a bad ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip. .
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.C7050: What is C7050? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for battery current sensing, you should measure around 2.202 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesnâ€™t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V 0A
threads.message:
Hi,
on this board, I get 20v 0A and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 1V with no short (diode mode 0,250)
At <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL> 5v
<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>/21/61/62 are ok
<SIGNAL>TBA_HPWR_EN_L</SIGNAL> 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 5V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_R_L</SIGNAL> / <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_R</SIGNAL> 3.4V
<SIGNAL>SMC_CHGR_INT_L</SIGNAL> 3.4V
<SIGNAL>CHGR_ACOK</SIGNAL> 3,3V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RST_IN</SIGNAL> 0V
<SIGNAL>PD_SMC_CBC_ON</SIGNAL> 0V
<RESISTOR>R7075</RESISTOR> is 5ohms and <SIGNAL>TBA_VDDA</SIGNAL> is 5V
<SIGNAL>VR1_3P3</SIGNAL> is 3.4V 
A/BMON 0V
<SIGNAL>TBA_COMP</SIGNAL> is 1,125V noticed it was 1,6 and 1,5V on working board

What can I do?
Thanks
Best regards

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V 0A
threads.message: Did you change <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V 0A
threads.message:
no I don't change <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, I haven't new one but I have board to keep it but I don't know if <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is good. 
I try and come back

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V 0A
threads.message: ok i change <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, same problem

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V 0A
threads.message:
Check if you get same voltages above mentioned.

Remove F7000 and check <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> voltage then.
Be sure <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> has correct voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V 0A
threads.message:
i have <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> without F7000 13V with F7000 1V, I think it's a short on PPBUS but small short (diode mode 0,250)
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is OK 3,4V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V 0A
threads.message:
What is diode mode on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> in reverse way (black probe at ground)?
Compare with the readings on all big coils.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V 0A
threads.message: L7900=0,90 like <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, if I diode mode between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and  <SIGNAL>PPVCCPCH_S5G</SIGNAL> =0

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V 0A
threads.message:
Do you get 0.250/0.900 at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and L7900 too?
0 ohm between both power rails means <TRANSISTOR>Q7900</TRANSISTOR> is shorted.
Remove it and check again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V 0A
threads.message:
ok i change <TRANSISTOR>Q7900</TRANSISTOR> but always 20V 0,038A
I have <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 13V
<SIGNAL>PPVCCPCH_S5G</SIGNAL> = 1V
PP5VS5=5V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V 0A
threads.message: What is VCORE voltage (L7210/20) after 10-15s?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V 0A
threads.message:
VCORE L7210/20 = 0V after 30s
maybe CPU is burn?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V 0A
threads.message: Post voltage on all coils.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V 0A
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V 0A
threads.message:
Check if <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> comes high.
If not, trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check if pulses at least.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V 0A
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> = 0 and when I put <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> short to GND, I haven't pulses on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V 0A
threads.message: Do you note drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> (at same time)?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V 0A
threads.message:
Hi,
yes, when I push the button power, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> fall.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V 0A
threads.message:
Then you have POCH related problem.
Check its RTC signals first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V 0A
threads.message:
i have <SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL>=3,1 V
What is POCH problem?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V 0A
threads.message:
Sorry for misstyping; read PCH instead.
I asked about signals, not RTC power.

<SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> present?
